The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE. In connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suskin direct returning from Suskin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.

N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free. Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8.30 a.m. in time for Express to Switzerland, Paris and London leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages sand luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS, ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO. MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, MANSOURAH AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital £1.500,000
Paid up £ 500,000
Reserve Fund £500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial houses and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 3 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deposited as they full due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers.

div.head: AKABA IN ANCIENT TIMES
div.p: AKABA IN ANCIENT TIMES.

Political events often bring into prominence the most out-of-the way places on this earth. Pendji and Fashoda ware little heard of until they became the scenes of events of serious and important political incidents. Now Akabah, an out-of-the-way place-town it can hardly be called, for it is a cluster of houses with an inferior bazaar which nestles under the walls of the Turkish fort—becomes the scene of a political episode which raises it in importance. The dispute over the Egyptian-Turkish frontier, which is now exercising the minds of politicians, is but the latest phase of a problem which has existed for thousands of years. As the Egyptians and the Turks now dispute over the line of demarcation, so the Assyrians and the Pharaohs disputed over the same matter in the early years of the eighth century before our era.

The neighbourhood of the Wady El Arish, the western terminus of the somewhat arbitrarily drawn frontier, has been the scene of two or more battles in ancient times which have had considerable influence on future history. In B.C. 714, Sargon, the victor of Samaria, defeated the Egyptian, or rather Ethiopian, Army at Raphia, betwren Gaza and El Arish; while, twelve years latter, Sennacherib overthrew the Syro Egyptian allies in the battle of Eltekeh, followed by the siege of Jerusalem, and the submission of Hezekiah. The frontier line in dispute passes across the limestone plateau of Et-Tih, the desert of the wanderings, and terminates at Akabah. Two roadways cross this arid dersert, which resembles the Sahara in its barrenness, deserted by man and beast. The first is the Haj, or Pilgrim, road, which started from Ismailia, or Kantara, "the bridde," and terminated at Akabah, where the caravans halted prior to continuing their weary jonrney along the coast of Arabia to Jeddah and Mecca. The road is now but little used, and consequently, the inhabitants of Akabah do not reap the rich harvest they formerly did. A second road of much greater importance and antiquity is the Syrian road, which terminates at Gazs. This is one of the oldest trade routes in the world, being the channel by which the wealth of Midian Edom and Yemen was conveyed to Syria and Egypt. It was in use long before the time of Solomon, and was the route by which the Midianite merchants carried Joseph into Egypt. It was certainly used by traders and others as early as the Twelfth Egyptian Dynasty, and was the route by which Sinuit fled to Midian in the reign of Amen-em-hat III. It is frequently referred to in the Minean inscriptions, and in a text of the Persian period there is a reference to the deliverence of some merchants from the King of Persia beyond the river, probably Cambyses, then advancing on Egypt.

During the Crusades it was in their hands, and Rainald du Chatillon was in 1182 Governor of Akabah. The town of Akabah is also of historical importance, though little remains to it now. Situated at the head of the gulf to which it gives its name, which is to be identified as the Biblical Gulf of Elak, it represents the emporium which Solomon founded on the Red Sea for trade with the mythical Ophir. Forming as it does the terminus of the great fault or gorge which runs from the north of Palestine south, and includes in its depression the Jordan valley, the Lake of Galilee, the Dead Sea—with the rocky channel of the Wady Akabah—it represents the outlet, no doubt, of some great river bed which in far remote ages had its month in the gulf. The surface water which rolls down from the slopes of El Shara and the Wady Akabah brings sufficient nourishment for a fringe of palm groves and vegetation to clothe the shore, and to form a pleasing variation to the arid desert and glaring rocks which are all around.

The prosperity of the part in ancient times has now disappeared, and indeed there is considerable doubt as to it having existed. Of the travellers who have visited the site Ruppell, Burkbart, Belle, and later Sir R. Burton and Mr. Wilfrid Blunt, none of them appear to have been able to find any trace of really ancient ruins. The only remains of antiquity are found on the island of Farun—Pharaoh's island, near Wasit—but this, as now seen, does not appear to be older than Roman times; but certainly occupied and enlarged in crusading times, and afterwards occupied by Saladin, who in 1167 A.D. is said to have driven the Infidels out by carrying ships on camel back from Cairo. If the ruins are not antique, there is a decided evidence of racial antiquity in the inhabitants of this and the opposite coast They differ entirely from the Bedouin, being lighter in colour, more active, and indeed might be oonsidered to have some Somali affinities. They are found all along the Arabian coast north of Jeddah. Their source of livelihood is ostensibly pearl and coral fishing, but many a crew of coasting vessels has found that they make first class pirates. Only a few months ago a native dhow from Suakin was wrecked on this coast, stripped of everything valuable, and the crew are still missing.

During recent years Akabah has revived a little owing to the completion of the Damascus Maan railway, which it is intended to extend to this town; and its forerunner, the telegraph, has reached it already. The Turks during the interminable Yemen rebellion have conveyed troops to Maan by rail and marched them down to Akabah, taking them thence by sea to the seat of war. The reported 5,000 men at Akabah now is probably a great exaggeration of numbers, for they would soon at the inhabitants out of house and home. The troops here are probably waiting conveyance to Yemen. Of the fort at Dhaba or Tabah, there appears to have been no knowledge until recently, and it does not appear on any map, not even on the Egyptian official map, and I am inclined to agree with Mr. W. S. Blunt, who regards it as a very modern construction. One word of warning to those who imagine a great future for this region. We hear constantly of gold and copper mines in these regions, and of great developments; but in a land which lacks all the essentials of commercial succeses—water, wood, coal, and, above all, labour—sucb mining operations are impossible, and in addition the natives are true sons of Ishmael, with their hand against every man and every man's hand against them, ("The Globe").

div.head:
AMERICA'S MOST APPALLING DISASTER
FRISCO FIRE UNDER CONTROL
RELIEF MEASURES

div.p: The Mayor of San Francisoo has issued a proclamation to the effect that the fire is under control.
The American insurance companies have decided to pay all claims. It is believed that altogether 110,000,000 dollars will be paid to San Francisco policy-holders. (Reuter)

At San Francisco the homeless are encamped in the parks and open spaces, the wealthy alongside the poorest: all efforts are concentrated on sheltering and rationing: the people are very orderly: great hopes are entertained of saving the suburb called Western Addition and northwards to Presidio, but the fire along the Waterfront is still uncontrolled and fanned by a strong northwest wind which threatens the ferry, the only means of egress from the city. The broken watermains are being restored. Operatic stars, including Signor Caruso and Sembrich, escaped in night attire, one artist barefooted and in pyjamas clutching his violin.

President Roosevelt recommended Congress to vote an additional 1,500,000 dollars for the relief of the sufferers at San Francisco, as it appears that the disaster is the most appalling one in the history of the country. All the mails in the Post Office were saved and 11 of the clerks were extricated alive but unconscious, having been foodless and waterless for three days. (Reuter
The fire along the waterfront at San Francisco is under control: the ferry is safe and trains are beginning to run. (Reuter)
Violent earthquake shocks ware felt at Poggibonsi and Colle Val d'Elsa (Tuscany). The panic-stricken inhabitants have taken flight into the country. Several houses have been damaged. (Havas)

div.head:
FRENCH STRIKE DISTUBANCES
PITCHED BATTLE WITH TROOPS

div.p: A regular pitched battle has taken place beween 6,000 strikers and a detachment of Dragoons, between Denain and Haveluy: the Dragoons were compelled to release the prisoners: two captains and 10 troopers were wounded. The strikers then proceeded to Haveluy and sacked the houses. (Reuter)
The situation in North France continues to be serious: disturbances have taken place at Demain and Lievin, where strikers erected barricades. (Reuter)
The strike is general. Disturbances have taken place. Several persons have been injured. (Havas)
Eight thousand more reinforcements have arrived at Lens : there are now 210,000 troops in the mining distiict. (Reuter)

div.head:
OLYMPIC GAMES
OPENED BY KING GEORGE

div.p: The Olympic Games were opened to-day in the Stadium by the King of Greece,accompanied by the King and Queen of England and the Prince and Princess of Wales : an impressive procession of 900 athletes took place. (Reuter)

After a speech by Prince Constantine, the King of Greece inaugurated the Olympic Games. King Edward wore the uniform of a Greek admiral, which title had been conferred on him by King George. The crowd was innumerable. (Havas)
Two train loads of constabulary have gone to guard the Swaziland frontier. (Reuter)
637 bales of West African cotton were landed at Liverpool. (Reuter)
Madame Curie will continue her husband's researches. (Reuter)
Major General Sir Gerald Morton. (Reuter)
Association Football Cup Match. Everton beat Newcastle United by one to nil. There were over 60,000 spectators. (Reuter)

div.p: Our Ghirgeh Correspondent telegraphs that a big conflagration has broken out at Kom bandar.

div.head: New Company.
div.p: We draw our readers' attention to the prospectus of the Egypt and Levant Steamship Company.
Alhambra Theatre.
Eh Comment! en 2000, a "revue d'actualites Alexandrines," by Henri Yan, will be produced at this theatre tomorrow evening.
Alexandria Archaeological Society.
The third excursion organised by the above society will take place on Thursday next. Persons taking part will meet at the Chatby necropolis, which can be reached by tram, carriage, or automobile.
Corporation of Western Egypt.

Three feet of carbonaceous material, of the nature of lignite, was struck at a depth of 450 feet by this company on the ground where well boring is now continuing in the neighbourhood of the Khargeh Oasis.
Concert.

An evening entertainment (songs, recitations, musical solos, sketches, etc.) will be held in the saloons of Shepheard's Hotel on Wednesday next, at 9.30 p.m., in aid of the British Soldiers' and Sailors' Families Association.
Cairo Scientific Society.

A meeting of the society will take place at the Schoo1 of Medicine on Thursday, the 26th inst., at 430 p.m. A paper will be read by Mr. J. J. Craig on "The Southerly Winds of Egypt'' and by Mr. W. L. Balls on "The Mechanism of Nuclear Division."
Englishwoman's Mysterious Death.

The death of an Englishwoman was the subject of the investigations of a court of enquiry held this morning at the British Consulate at Alexandria. The deceased's name was Jessie Browne and she was a stewardess on board of the Khedivial Mail's S.S. Assouan. She died from taking corrosive sublimate but whether intentionally or not is as yet unknown, for the Court was still sitting as we went to press.
Mohamed Aly Industrial School.

The building of this great Moslem educational establishment at Alexandria is rapidly approaching completion and the entire school should be finished and ready for work about this time next year. It will be a very fine building and should go a very long way to affording the native youths of Alexandria every aid towards a complete technical educational equipment.

div.head: DUKE OF THE ABRUZZI AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Sunday.

The Duke of the Abruzzi and suite were among the passengers by the German steamer Burgemeister, which sailed from Suez last night. The expedition of the Duke, consisting of naval and military officers and Alpine guides, will land at Mombasa and thence proceed through the centre of Africa to ascend Mount Ruvenzore, which so far has been unexplored.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive left Alexandria for Cairo on Saturday evening. His Highness came in to Abdeen Palace to-day from Koubbeh and presided at the Council of Ministers.
The Khedive will hold a final reception at Cairo prior to his Highness's departure for Alexandria on Saturday next at Abdeen Palace.

div.head: THE PRINCES CASE
div.p: This most interesting lawsuit will he pleaded on Wednesday and Thursday next before the Mixed Courts and should be very largely attended. The heirs of Ismail Pacha will he represented by Mes. Vella and Manusardi. The former will plead on Wednesday morning, the latter on Thursday morning, while Me. Pietri, of the Contentieux, who is representing the Government, will be heard on Wednesday afternoon. The case will then be held over for a week, after which the "Ministere publique" will give his conclusions.

div.head: MUNICIPALITIES COMMISSION
div.p: The Higher Commission of the Municipalities met on Saturday at the Ministry of the Interior under the presidency of Ibrahim Pasha Neguib, Under Secretary of State. It was decided to connect the Nile bank with the shore of the Menzaleh lake at Damietta by a road. The Ministry of Finance has been requested to open the necessary credit of L E. 3,600 for the scheme.
The Commission also decided to supply the sakkas of Mit Ghamr with artesian well water at a low price.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Khephren sailed from Liverpool, via Malta, with mails and a cargo of 23,057 bags onions.
The Cunard S. S. Cypria arrived at Liverpool on Saturday morning.
The S. S. Orestes (Westcott and Laurance Line) left Malta on Friday and is due here to-morrow with general cargo from London.
The S. S. Creole Prince, from Alexandria, arrived at Manchester on the 21st inst.

div.head: INCREASE OF BRITISH GARRISON
NATIVE PRESS OPINIONS
div.p: Native Press opinions on the increase of the Army of Occupation are decidedly interesting. The "Moayad," after denying the statement that Ghazi Mukhtar Pacha had claimed for Turkey the right to construct a line to Suez which would place Egypt at the mercy of an Ottoman army, continues : "Now that the pilgrim route has been changed, Tabah becomes of no importance to Egypt and the Suzerain Empire, which has already reoccupied all the posts on the E. side of the Gulf of Akaba, wishes to come into possession of Tabah for the same purpose, viz., in the interests of the pilgrims. In our opinion it has every right to do so. We fail to see the threats, on which English newspapers have enlarged, in the Ghazi's answer. After all, his Excellency is not responsible for the deductions of over-excited journalists. What then is the chief object of this augmentation of our Army of Occupation at a moment when all is profoundly peaceful in the country and Egyptians see in the Tabah question nothing that concerns them deeply, and are ready to agree to any solution of the difficulty? (The italics are ours). The decision has then been taken against the Ottoman Empire and not against Egypt and its people.…. The policy is unwise ; it can only draw the attention of Egyptians to something far more important than the actual dispute: The question whether England intends to push the Akaba question to a point where the relations between the two countries would be dangerously strained. Is this to England's advantage? Can England depend on the Egyptian Government so far in a quarrel over the insignificant post of Tabah? And can the Egyptian Government follow England to the end?

The "Lewa" is briefly indignant. "Great Britain," says our contemporary, has decided to reinforce her garrison in Egypt, and yet there is nothing in the country to call for such a decision, especially as Lord Cromer does not need an army to realise his wishes in the Egyptian Government but does so with the assent of the Egyptian authorities, and by the issue of the necessary decrees. The reason of the increase is attributable to the occupation of Tabah by the Turks. Whom, then, does England want to threaten? Is it the Egyptians who, if they are interested in this matter, are so out of a natural sentiment that none can question? Does she desire thereby to threaten the Ottoman Empire? We know that there is not a Turk who allows himself to be influenced by these threats which have no effect on the policy of the Empire. Does she desire to further annoy the Egyptians? We are in a position to assure her that the Egyptians are driven quite wild about the Occupation and that she need not employ fresh methods to attain this end.''

Of "Al Ahram" we have already spoken. "Al Watan" has devoted two articles to the subject. In the first it remarks: "This increase, like the Occupation, may be useful to us (i.e., the Copts). But England has a reason for this action, especially since the present Government has all along opposed any increase of expenditure on the Empire's military forces."

The article concludes vaguely with the remark that while the Akaba affair has perpaps been the cause of this action by H.B.M.'s Government nothing can be definitely known. In any case the sudden increase will be a good lesson.

In a second article "Al Watan" expresses its conviction that Lord Cromer is alone responsible for the increase of the British forces in Egypt, and, unheard of comment, declares that newspapers ought not to lay down the law on subjects on which they know nothing. We had thought that that was their "raison d'etre."

We heartily agree with "Al Watan" in deprecating all bluster against the Turkish High Commissioner which will very likely have the opposite effect to that intended. The Government will certainly not follow any such course.

"Al Gawareb el Masrieh" says:—"What signification is to be given to the decision of the British Cabinet to increase the effective of the British garrison in Egypt ? Who knows the truth? Simple folk attribute it to a crisis between the Egyptian and Turkish Governments. But this hypothesis has been refuted by the declarations of the British Foreign Office. Other and wiser heads consider that it is merely an answer to the increase of the Ottoman force at Akaba. This hypothesis is more probable, and if it be correct no one and nothing are the worse for the change—except the Egyptian Treasury.

"Germany may be in the background but we know that her intervention is not dangerous for she has before now given ground at the last moment. We therefore request the Ghazi and our own diplomats not to push matters too far and so avoid all unpleasant consequences of the dispute. The Egyptian nation wishes to see no hindrance to the economic development of the country, which it considers of far greater importance than Tabah and Akaba. Finally, we hope than none of our clever heads will foment troubles here as they did when the Macedonian question was raised and that diplomats of the two countries will be allowed to settle the dispute in a manner advantageous to both sides."

div.head: STORES FOR AKABA
div.p: Suez, Sunday.
The cruiser Nour El Bahr sailed yesterday for Akaba with stores for H. M. S. Diana.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HORTICULTURAL EXHIBITION
div.p: The annual exhibition of the Alexandria Horticultural Society was held at San Stefano on Saturday and yesterday, and was on both days visited by large crowds of people, the attendance, we believe, exceeding that of last year. The show was opened as usual by H. H. the Khedive, who arrived at the Casino with his accustomed punctuality at 4 p.m. on Saturday, accompanied by H. E. the Governor.

His Highness was received at the entrance by H. H. Prince Hussein Pacha Kamel, Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, and the other members of the committee, who accompanied the Khedive on his tour of the building and tents. His Highness evinced the greatest interest in all he saw and after congratulating the committee on the success of their efforts, departed, as he had arrived, attended by the Governor and suite. Immediately after the Khedive's departure the general public were admitted to view the exhibits.

The two principal features of this year's show were the great interest that was taken in Prince Hussein's £30 prize pelargoniums and the enormous number of exhibits of vegetables. The pelargoniums were sufficient in number to fill a large tent and the exhibits of vegetables were over 600 in number. The committee initiated a new movement this year, which was, that on Sunday morning they arranged with M. Monfront, the capable gardener of the Municipality, who had been one of the vegetable judges, to give an object- lesson to the natives in order that the latter should understand how to stage their exhibits and how to select their vegetables for the show.

The large ballroom of the Casino was crowded with valuable plants grown in hothouses. In the middle of the room were three groups of caladiums, in which class the competition was extremely keen between M. Zervudachi and M. Kindinico. To the ordinary public it seemed as if M. Kindinico, who only obtained the second prize, had the more beautiful collection, but doubtless the judges were influenced in favour of M. Zervudachi because of the fact that the leaves of his plants were finer, and were perhaps grown more according to the ideas of the present day, which, we believe, are to withdraw the smaller leaves to give strength to the larger. The four enormous groups of crotons had a pleasing effect from the variety of their leaves. M. Salvago well deserved the first prize, as the plants were covered with foliage from the bottom of the stems, and were well-grown plants. The three other groups certainly exceeded those of former years, and amongst them the group of Hassan Bey Rassem showed an extraordinarily beautiful variety of tints on the leaves. M. E. C. Zervudachi's large group had the merit of containing several fine plants which we have seen in former years, thereby showing the attention he must pay to his garden in order to keep such specimens as marautha, theoriums, etc., which require so much care to keep them in a healthy condition. The Begonia Rex, which are generally such a feature of the Alexandria Show, were somewhat of a disappointment this year; all the usual competitors seemed to have failed from one cause or another with the exception of M. Kindinico, who staged a good group. There was a remarkable exhibit (not for competition) of orchids, shown by Hassan Bey Rassem, placed on a long table, and near by were the orchids of M. Zervudachi, one of which was never known to flower before in Egypt. So overcrowded was the ballroom that another room had to be requisitioned for the fine palms of M. Salvago, the antheriums of Bartau Bey, and the two fine specimen plants which were placed close to the entrance.

A feature of the Alexandria show has always been the enormous groups of palms and zonal pelargoniums. These filled almost the whole of the largest tent and were quite equal to former years. The only other exhibit of importance in this tent was a good collection of carnations, staged by Mme Debbane. The progress which has been made by the Municipality since the gardens were taken over by M. Monfront was shown by the large collection of nearly every kind of annual which he staged. In consequence of Prince Hussein having graciously offered an object d'art of the value of £30, great interest has been taken in pelargoniums. The prize was won by Mr. L. Sanders with forty good plants covered with flowers of nearly every shade imaginable. The pelargoniums had been well-grown, were staged with effect, and merited the prize. Mme Debbane was near enough for the judges to award her a silver medal. Fine collections were also staged by M. Benachi, M. Salvago, and others.

The silver gilt medal offered by the Royal Horticultural Society of London for the best collection of roses as cut flowers was awarded to Mr. Sandars, the silver medal going to M. Kindinico. Mrs. Crafton staged the best rose in the show. Mr. Percy Carver always shows a good collection of sweetpeas and as a true amateur of flowers, never fails to give the proper names. He showed two boxes this year, but we are not sure that they were so good as those we saw three years ago. Mrs. Borchgrevink's anemones, iris, and large collection of cut flowers all won first prizes, and among the new competitors who distinguished themselves were Mrs. Borton and Mrs. Richmond.

The table decorations this year were not so numerous as usual. Miss Hewat took first prize with a design in yellow roses and dark foliage, Mrs. Magnus the second with an arrangement of red pelargoniums, and Miss G. T. Atkin was highly commended for a table with salmon coloured roses ; but the feature of the room was certainly Miss E. B. Atkin's original idea of decorating a table as a reminiscence of the first show held at San Stefano. The flowers were placed in little boxes, similar to the boxes in which exhibits are shown in the tent of cut flowers. The names of the exhibitors were added and the flowers selected were those generally exhibited by the members who gained the prizes. Miss Atkin had even remembered those who generally stage vegetables and she had grouped probably the smallest potatoes, cabbages, asparagas, &c., that have ever been seen at an exhibition.
The prettiest vase of flowers was that shown by Mme Zervudachi with yellow broom, and Miss Hewat obtained two prizes for flowers which had been most artistically arranged.

Amongst the vegetables staged by amateurs, the large group shown by Bartau Bay, for which a silver medal was awarded, and the collection of Mr. F. Haselden well merited attention. The native exhibits occupied a large amount of space and were certainly an improvement on former years.
The following were the judges:–
Pot Plants and Cut Flowers : Messrs. Ebell, Eggert, Ghyseln, Hassan Rassem Bey, Seffer and Tramontina.
Table Decorations: Mesdames Bird, Gescher, and Peel.

div.head: BULLETIN DB LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujcwrthmi à midi et demie)
La matinée a été toute entière oonaaorée anz Port Said Salt Association et aux Salt and Soda.
Ces dernière? ont clôturé à 23/3 et les Port Said Salt à 15/3 aobetenrs.
Quant an reste, il y a fléshissement général, excepté ei Agricole qui hausse an contraire à 10 1/8—10 3/16.
Quelques affaires ont également été traitées en Trust à 1 21/32.
L'Oasis (Corporation of Western Egypt) est invendable à 1 1/4. Da 33/6 la New Egyptian tombe à 31/9 et les Upper Egypt Hotels de 5 3/16 à 4 3/4.

Cette réaction est probablement appelée à s'accentuer bien davantage d'ici à la fin du mois, oar il saffit d'ane vente de 25 titres poor occasionner une dégringolade, comme cela est arrivé ce matin pour le Crédit Franoo- Egyptien.

div.head: The Port Said Salt Association, Limited
div.p: Les assemblées Extraordinaires et Ordinai res de la Port Said Salt Association, Ltd., ont eu lieu, Samedi, aveo un concours inusité d'actionnaires. Il y avait plus de 60 actionnaires et 135.000 actions étaient représentées. Les propositions faites par le groope d'actionnaires intéressés dans la Sait Soda, en vue d'amener la fusion des deux Sociétés ont été rejetées à une énorme majorité. L'Assemblée Ordinaire a approuvé le rapport, a décidé de distribuer le dividende de 5 %, a nommé Administrateurs M:M. Vermond et Geo. Sait, en remplacement dés deux administrateurs sortants qui ne se présentaient pas à la réélection et a nommé Mr. Hewat, censeur. A la suite de l'Assemblée, MM. Debourg et R. Abdy administrateurs ont donné leur démission.

div.head: CORRESPONDANCE
div.p: Nous ne nommes pas responsables dos opinions emises par nos correspondants, mais nous désirons, dans un esprit de loyale polémique, permettre—dans certaines limites nécés saires—unellbre discussion.

div.head: PORT SAID SALT ASSOCIATION AND SALT AND SODA COMPANY.
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur de l'Egyptian Gazette
L'Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire qui a eu lieu samedi a été très? animée contrairement anx habitudes d'Alexandrie.

C'est l'apologie de la Sait and Soda qui a eu les honneurs de la journée. L'Administrateur Délégué de cette Sooiété a parlé admirablement bieu et rien n'a manqué dans ses arguments pour impressiorner les actionnaires de la Port- Said : désir du Gouvernement pour que la fusion se fasse, ce qui a été contesté ; le Wadi Natroun est une mine d'or, mais pour le mo ment cela ne représente que des espérances ; finalement, et o'est le point important, l'Ad ministrateur Délégué de la Sait and Soda a déolaré que sa Sooiété n'admettant pas une concurrence quelconque avait décidé qu'aussi- tôt que la Port-Said 8alt commencera à vendre du sel dans l'Intérieur, elle vendrait dans les villages son sel au prix des transports de Port-Said dans les diverses villes de l'inférieur, sans olonler la valeur du sel ; que la Sait and Soda aveo l'exploitation des huileries et savon neries, pondre, etc. gagnera environ £35,000 et qu'elle n'avait pas besoin du sel pour donner un dividende à ses actionnaires. Ces déclara rions sont de nature à faire réfléchir les action naires de la Sait and Soda, et oomme tel je trouve que si réellement de telles décisions ont été priée? nos dividendes futurs risquent beaucoup. J'ai sous les yeux le rapport de la Sait and Soda au 31. août 1905 pour 17 moi* d'exercice, et j'y rélève que l'exploitation commerciale des huileries et savonneries, vente du sel. déduorionfaite des frais, a rapporté £52,559. mais je vois de l'autre côté : Salaire?, frais d'dministration
Service des obligations ... £ 6,604 £24,351
Bénéfices ... ... £28,208
y compris oeux du sel.

S'il y a lutte entre les deux Sociétés la Sait and Soda dit poavoir compter sur les bénéfices des huileries qui suivant ce que disait l'administrateur délégué s'élèveront à ... £35/00 je dédois la proportion de 17,745 pour
le service des obligations ... £ 6,604 £19,150
Restent £15,850.

Cela suffirait pour donner le 3 % s/ le capital mais comme la vente du sel non seulement ne rapportera rien, et sera au contraire passive de tous les frais généraux incombant à cette branche, frais qui doivent être énorme?, il y a à prévoir que cette évaluation de bénéfices se transformera en perte. Je ne sais ce qae fera la Port Said Salt mais sans rien perdre elle peut jeter sur les mar chés de l'intérieur une certaine quantité de rel afin d'obliger la Sait and Soda à maintenir sa politique de travail à perte, et dans cette lutte je crains bien que ce ne soit le colosse qui doivent finalement céder.
Qu'en pensent les actionnaires de la Sait and soda ?
Un Actionnaire de 14 Salt and Soda. 27778-1

div.head: The Upper Egypt Hotels Company
div.p: MM. les actionnaires sont informés que le dernier versement de £1 par action est paya- b'e le premier mai 1906. Les paiements doivent être effectués à la National Bank of Egypt, qui délivrera un reça. Ce reçu doit être présenté avec le Certificat Provisoire aux bureaux de MM. Rnpell Kerr & Wyatt pour l'endossement du montant.
A partir dp la même date les Certificats Provisoires peuvent être échangés contre titres an poitenr anx mêmes boréaux. 27773 3A-1

div.head: Egyptian Constructions, Limited
div.p: Notice is hereby given that the Directors of the Egyptian Constructions, Limited, have this day resolved that a Call of Five Shillings per share be made upon the partly paid shares of the Company, payable on or before the 3rd day of May 1906.
Share Certificates, together with the amount due, viz:—5s. per share, must be presented to the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Limited, Cairo or Alexandria, within the time above-mentioned.
By Order of the Board, A. P. Phillips. Secretary.

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie.
div.p: AVIS CONCERNANT LES RATS.
Cette époque de Tannés ocmoidant avjc la réapparition de la peste, les autorités sanitaires croient devoir rappe'er le rôle prépondérant qne jouent les rats dans la propagation de cette épidémie.

Elles engagent les habitants de la Ville et principalement les personnes qui sont parti onlièrement exposées aa oontaot des rats (telles qne bakals, marchand? d'huile, de farine, de savon, propriétaires d'écuries, eto ) à faire asage des ratières et des boulettes empoisonnées que la Municipalité met gratuitement à leur disposition.

Les autorités sanitaires accordent une prime de P.T. 20 pour tout rat qui aura été reconnu atteint, ou seulement suspect de peste. Toutes les toi? qu'on voudra faire parvenir dans ce bat, des rat? au laboratoire, on s'abstiendra de les y apporter eoi-même, mais on les mettra, en les prenant si possible aveo des pinoettes, dans un seau, et Ton préviendra la Municipalité ou l'Hôpital da Gouvernement.
L'Administrateur (Signé) W. P. Chatàway.
Alexandrie, le 21 Avril 1906. 27769-3-1

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien.
div.p: AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la oonnaissai c? du Public qu'à partir du 15 Mai 1906 les arti oies suivants : lèves, blés, maïs, orges, lentilles, helbés, lupins et pois chiches, qui seront transportés par charge complète oa inoomplète de toute? les gares de la Haute-Egypte situées au Sud d'Abou-el-Noamrous (inclusivement) destination des gares de la Basse-Egypte (y compris le Caire, Ghiz?b, Bonlao Daoroar et Embabeh), seront taxé? au taux de la 6me classe da Tarif Général des Marchandises, avec une rédaction de 25 %.

Cette rédaction s'étendra également sur les "Tibns" qui seront expédiés des gares de la Haute-Egypte au Sud d'Abou el-Nomrous (inclusivement) à destination des gares de la Basse Egypte (y compris les sus-mentionnées) par chargement complet (avec un minimum de 6,000 kilogs.) et tans responsabilité pour l'Administration.
Ces dispositions seront mises en vigueur jaeqn'au 31 Août 1906 et seront appliquées seu'emeut sur le prix de transport.
Las frais accessoires seront perças au complet.
Le Caire, le 18 Avril 1906. 27763-1

div.head: AVIS
div.p: POUR CAUSE DE LIQUIDATION

Lundi 80 avril 1906 à 9 heares da matin et jours suivants, il sera procédé par Teetremise de MonsieurLDella Torre,Commissaire Priseur, à la Vente aux Enchères Publiques,da Mobilier garnissant l'Hôtel da Nil, consistant notamment en Portes Manteaux d'Eutrée, garnitures de Salons, garnitares de Chambres à Coucher, garnitures de Salles à Manger, Lits anglais oomplets, Tapis persans et européens, Meables arabesques, glaces, Verrerie, Cristallerie, Argenterie Christofle, Métal blanc, Lingerie, Couvertures, Piano. Billard, Batteries de cai- sine en Cuivre et en fer émaillé, eto. etc.
La vente aura lieu dans l'Hôtel du Nil, situé Chareh Moasky.
L'acheteur devra payer au comptant plus le % pour droit de criée soit aax Enchères Publiques oa h l'amiable et retirer immédiatement les objets adjugés.—
L. DELLA TORRE,
Le Commissaire Priseur, Expert assermenté auprès des Tribunaux, de l'armée d'Ocoupa- tion et da gouvernement Egyptien.
On pourra visiter les dits Meubles, les jours de Vendredi, Samedi et Dimanche les 27, 28 et 29 avril 19 6, de 9 Inureî da mtiu à midi et de 3 à 6 heares de l'après-midi. 27745-8-1

div.head: Egypt and Levant Steamship
div.p: COMPANY, LIMITED. (To be Incorporated under the Companies' Acts, 1862 to l900.
Divided into 199,000 Ordinary Shares of £1 each, and 20,000 Deferred Shares of 1s. each.

The holders of the Ordinary Shares are eu titled (1) to a fixed cumulative dividend at the rate of 5% per annum on the capital for the time being paid up or credited as paid up thereon respectively, and to 60% of the surplus profits which in each year it shall from time to time be determined to distribute remaining after paying or providing for the payment of the said fixed cumulative dividend ; (2), to priority as to return of capital and payment off of arrears of dividend whether declared or not up to the commencement of the winding up.

The Deferred Shares confer on the holders thereof rateably and in proportion to the number of Deferred Shares held by them respectively the right to 4% of the surplus profits which in respect of each year it shall from time to time be determined to distribute remaining after paying or providing for the payment of the said fixed cumulative dividend on the Ordinary Shares.
Of the above 199,000 Ordinary Shares, $60,000 are payable as part of the Purchase- Money as mentioned herein, and 61,000 will be reserved for private subscription.
Subscriptions are invited from the public at par for 75,000 Ordinary Shares.
Payable 10% on Application, 15% oa Allotment, 25% On the 15th June, 1906 and the balance, viz., 50%, on the 15th July, 1906.

Share Warrants to Bearer will be delivered free of stamp duty to Original Subscribers upon payment of their Shares in full, but no payment in anticipation will carry with it any right to dividend on the amoont so paid in advance.

PROSPECTUS

This Company has been formed for the purpose specified in the Memorandum of Association and in particular (1) to take over and acquire the good will and business of the Talbot Steamship Company, Ltd., together with the existing fleet of steamers of the Com-pany, consisting of four steamers of large carrying capacity. (2) To acquire and/or build new steamers or other vessels. (3) To continue and develop the trade which has been carried on for the last 14 years by the Talbot Steamship Company between Smyrna and other Levant ports, Egypt and the United Kingdom. (4) Generally to carry on the business of shipowners in all its branches in the same or other parts of the world.

It is considered by the Directors of this company that the present is a favourable moment for extending the shipping business already developed by the Talbot Steamship Company, more particularly as there is every probability of there being favourable opportunity of acquiring new tonnage at low cost.

The Talbot Steamship Company has always enjoyed a high reputation in the Levant and has financially stood on a sound bassis ; like other shipping concerns, its profits have been affected at times by depression in freights, but bad and good years taken together the average net earnings over the whole period of its existence have been very satisfactory, in spite of heavy management charges, which, under the new arrangement, will be considerably reduced.
The volume of trade has so increased that additions to the fleet are absolutely necessary.

The shares of the Talbot Steamship Company, Ltd., are held in very few hands, and instead of further increasing its capital it has been determined to make over its present business and steamers to this company.

It is proposed to build, or, if a favourable opportunity offers, buy at once four new steamers, which, fitted with all the latest appliances, would be run on the most economical lines as to coal consumption, cost of working, etc.

It is confidently expected that with an increased fleet and facilities the new Company will at once take quite a leading position in the Levant as shipowners and command a steadily increasing clientèle amongst shippers.

The four steamers and their tackle, apparel, etc., to be taken over from the Talbot Steam ship Company, Ltd., have been valued by the well-known steamship valuers Messrs. Kellock & Co., of London, as follows: ––
S.S. Antonio, £28,500 ; S.S. Wingrove, £19,000 ; S.S. Cabral, £16,000 ; S.S. Hubbuck, £12,000 ; or a total of £75,500.
The value of the goodwill of the business of the Talbot Steamship Company, Ltd., has been fixed at £10,000 by that Company.

The Talbot Steamship Company, Ltd., whose registered offices is at 4, St. Mary Axe, London, E.C., has agreed to sell to Mr. J.D. Langdon, as a Trustee on behalf of the new Company, the whole of its gleet and the goodwill of its business at these prices, viz. £75,500 for the steamers and £10,000 for the goodwill, or a total of £85,500.
This price will be paid: £60,000 in fully paid Ordinary Shares of the Company and the balance in cash.
The business of the Talbot Steamship Company, Ltd., will be taken over as a going concern from the 1st May, 1906, and the Company will take all profits after that date.
The following contracrs have been entered into: ––

a Agreement dated the 12th April, 1906. Between the Talbot Steamship Company, Limited of one part and J.D. Langdon as trustee on behalf of the new Company of the other part providing for the sale of the above mentioned steamers and goodwill of the business at the above prices.

b Agreement dated the 12th April, 1906. Between the new Company of the one part and T. Bowen Rees and Company, Limited, of the other part whereby T. Bowen Rees and Company, Limited, are appointed the Managers of this Company at the following remuneration : (1) an allowance out of the annual profits of £200 per annum towards offices and clerks' salaries upon each steamer owned or managed by the Company ; (2) in every year in which the profits of the Company shall amount to 10 percent. or less upon the share capital for the time being paid up, an additional remuneration equal to 10 percent. on such net profits ; (3) in every year in which such profits shall exceed such 10 percent a remuneration equal to 15 per cent on such net profits, but in this event the Managers receive no remuneration under (2). The term "profits" means the earning of the steamers or other income of the company after charging steamers' working expenses, debenture interest, and interest on loans. The Managers are also entitled to charge the usual brokerage or commission, and agency fees when they act as loading or consigument brokers the customary brokerage on premiums of insurance, and the usual commission of 1 per cent for collecting and adjusting insurance claims.

(c) A Contract dated the 12th day of April, 1906, an l made between James Davee Langdon, of Smyrna, Merchant, , of the one part, and T. Bowen Rees, as a Trustee for and on behalf of this Company of the other part, whereby in consideration of an option given to Mr. J. D. Langdon to apply for and to have allotted to him all the Deferred Shares in the Company for which he will pay in cash, the said J. D. Langdon agrees to subscribe or to procure subscriptions for the whole of the present issue.
Sub underwriting contracts have been entered into by the said James Davee Langdon with various persons.
There are, in addition, contracts of an ordinary trade character which the Company will take over from the Talbot Steamship Company, Limited, as herein before mentioned.
Except the shares issued to the Talbot Steamship Company, Ltd., no shares of this issue will be issued as folly or partly paid up otherwise than in cash.
Except as aforesaid no promotion money will be paid.

The preliminary expenses of and incidental to the formation of the Company, down to and including allotment, including registration fees and stamp duty, legal expenses, the cost of advertising and issuing this prospectus, hot excluding stamp duty on share warrants and registration fees on transfer of the steamers, will be paid by the Company and are estimated at £3,000.
The number of Shares fixed by the Articles of Association as the qualification of a Director is 500 Ordinary Shares.
The following Directors are interested in the promotion of the Company and to the following extents —
Messrs. W. B. Rees, T. B. Rees and H. R. de Jongh are Shareholders in the Talbot Steamship Company Ltd. to the extent respectively of 100 shares, 152 shares and 40 shares of £100 each.

Mr. T. B. Rees owns almost the entirety of the share capital in T. Bowen Rees & Co., Ltd., the managers of the new company. Mr. H. Rr. de Jongh, as Manager of T. Bowen Rees and Company, Limited, is entitled to one-third of the net profits of that company.

Mr. H. E. Barker and Mr. T. Bowen Rees are interested as members of their respective company and firm as agents of the new Company in Smyrna and Alexandria and will be entitled to charge the usual brokerage or commission fees as loading or consignment brokers or agents.

Mr. Henry Laming, as sole partner in the firm of Alfred Laming and Company, who, it is proposed, will act as agents in London of the Company, will be entitled to the remuneration, not yet fixed, to be received by such agents from the Company.
Any Director who may sub-underwrite any shares of this issue will receive as the nominee of Mr. J. D. Langdon an allotment of deferred shares for which he will pay.
The provisions of the Articles of Association with regard to the remuneration of the Directors are as follows : —

"As remuneration for their services each of the Directors (other than the ex officio Directors, who being the Managers shall receive no remuneration for acting as Directors) shall be paid out of the funds of the Company in each year a sum calculated at the rate of £100 fur each steamer owned by the Company ; this remuneration will be equally divided between the Directors, unless they shall otherwise determine. The Company in

General Meeting shall have power from time to time to vary or alter each remuneration of the Directors in such manner as it shall think fit. If any Director, not being an ex officio Director, shall be called upon to perform extra services or to make any special exertions for the purposes of the Company, the Company shall remunerate the Director so doing, either by a fixed sum or by a percentage of profits, or otherwise as may be determined by the Directors, and such remuneration may be either in addition to or in substitution of his remuneration, as provided in the last preceding article."

Application for shares should be made on the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company's Bankers, the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Ltd., at Alexandria and Cairo. If no allotment is made the application money will be returned in foil and where the number of shares allotted is less than the number applied for the surplus will be credited in reduction of the amount payable on allotment and any excess will be returned to the applicant.
Failure to pay any instalment of shares, when due, will render previous payments liable to be forfeited.

The minimum subscription upon which the Directors may proceed to allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association at 10 per cent, of the shares offered. The whole of the present issue of shares has, however, as stated above, been underwritten.
A copy of the Memorandum of Association which forms part of this prospectus is endorsed hereon.
A brokerage of 3d. per share will be paid to Bankers and Brokers on all shares applied for and allotted to the public on forms of application which bear their stamps.

The valuation of Messrs. Kellock & Co., and the above-mentioned contracts or copies of these documents, together with a print of the Company's Memorandum and Articles of Association may be inspected at the offices of the Comptoir Financier et Commercial d'Egypte and of the Legal Adviser to the Company at Alexandria.

Copies of this prospectus and application forms can be obtained at the same offices and at the offices of the Bankers of the Company at Cairo and Alexandria. Dated Alexandria, 21st April, 1906. 27770-1-8

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, le 21 avril.
Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres vient d'etre enoore 41ev4 de 1/8 à 3 1/2 ponr cent. On lira pins loin les oanses de oe renohdrisee-ment du loyer del'argent.

A a Stock Exchange, le Consolid4 anglais aurait baiss4 hier de 5/8. saof errenr de transmission. L'Unifi4e a r4actionn4 de 1/4 à 106. La National Bank et 1'Agricole sont reat4es k 27 et. 10 1/8. La Daira a recoil de 1/4 à 18. La Delta a 4galement perdu 1/4 à 12 3/4.
A Paris, l'aotion Credit Foncier Egyptien s'est maintenne à 787. La Banqne d'Aihknes a regagn4 1 frano à 153.

Influence par les manvais conrs de Londres, notre marché a commence par se montrer lonrd et oraintif; la tendance generate etait k la reaction, aveo pen d'affaires. On a ete toatefois pins aotif et pins ferme vers la cldtare.
La National Bank, d4laiss4e, est tombee à 26 13/16 poor se relever à 26 15/16 27. L'Agri-cole, plus anim4e, a retrograde jnsqn'k 10 1/16 ponr oldturer à 10 1/8-3/16.
Le Comptoir a ete neglige à 8. La nonvelle emission de 50,000 actions, offsites par preference aox porteurs aotuels an prix de £ 5, est annonc4e poor le 2 Mai prochain.
L'action Credit Foncier est restee k 786 ; la part de fondatenr a hausse de 960 à 1010. La Delta Light a baisse à 12 1/2.

L'action Heliopolis a ete ramenee à 330 ; la part de fondatenr à 12 1/2. L'aotion Entre prises lmmobilteres et Travanx a ete ootee k 4 3/8; la part de fondatenr à 83. Les parts de fondateur Express Nile Steamers Co. ont ete echangees à 68-70. La part de fondatenr Nile Land a progrease à 70 ; Taction a fait 14 3/8.

Eq excellent* tenoe, les Improvements ont avance à 4 15/16. C'est justice, car oe titre est fort bon à prendre et ea valeur reelle est superiors an oonrs actnel. Le dividende distri-hne ponr 1905 represente an intent annael de!3% et l'exeroioe coarant s'annonoe sons lesmeillenrs anspioes.Cette eoci4t4afaitdepnis qoelque temps, soit aveo ses propres ressonroes, soit en participation, de belles operations qui font prevoir, à ooort delai, de trfca gros benefices.
Les actions privilegiees Tramways d'Alexandrie ont baisse à 190 ; les dividendes à 352. L'aotion Bourse Khediviale du Caire a reonie k 160 ; les Omnibus à 30.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nungovioh ont oldture à 17 15/16 et les Upper Egypt k 4 7/8.

Parmi lrs petites valears, il y a en de grosses ventes de Salt and Soda qui, de 26 sh.. sont tombes à 24 sb. 9, sur la romeur que le projet de fusion aveo la Port-Said Association serait appeie à Otre rejete par la majorite des aotion naires de cette deraifcre Sootetd. On a c'dtur4 k 25.
Les Delta Land re sont hien comports: de 4 5/8 ils ont progress^ à 4 13/16. Les Hooketr ont oldturl à 1 1/8-3/16. Lss Markets ont avancl à 27 sh. Les Abdy sont revenns k 1 5/16.
Nous extrayona d'une lettre de Londres, en date da 15 avril, les lignes suivantes relatives k la hausie da taax de I'esoompte :

"Le renoh5rissement da loyer de Targent est dfi à plusieurs causes : d'ahord an fait que le oours du change à New-York a fteohi dans des proportions extraordinaires : le "gold point" ayant 4*4 atteint, la Bauque d'Angleterre a dfi, Taut re jour, livrer £ 425,000 d'or pour les Etats-Uuis. On s'attend à la continuation de oette exode, mais on ne ressent anenne orainte B4rieose. Le seal mal est qn'ane fois enoore la baisse du taox de Tesoompte est arr6t4e. Snr le maroh4 libre on est remont4 à 3 1/8 et apparemment on ira à 3 1/2 avant la fin dn mois. Le taax da report s'en est ressenti en Bourse.

"D'aatre part, à Berlin, le poids de Tern-prnnt de 560 millions de marks p4sera assez lonrdement sur le maroh4, pendant qaelqne temps an moins. Anssi bien la Banqne de TEmpire n'a pas ahandonc4 le taux offioiel de 5 pour cent, et en Bourse le report ne s'4carte gukre de ce m6me taux.
"Enfiu, à Paris, la grosre affaire de l'em-prant rasse a amec4 le rappel des cpitaux framjais qui avaient oheroh4 emploi à Londres.

"En conclusion, Tassant g4n4ral livr4 aux diaponibilit^a a exerc4 one influence fkoheuse snr la tenne des Bourses. II en est r4solt4 une situation pins ou moins malais4e; mais henreu-sement cette g6ne est appel4e k dtre patsagkre, et il n'y a pas à appr4hender one crise grave." • *
Il resulte do rapport qui sera pr4sent4 k la proohaine assemble des Tramways d'Alexandra que le soldo cr4diteor du compte Profits et Pertes pour Texercice 1905 se monte k Frs. 642,102.

Apres avoir port4 Frs. 32,105 à la r4serve statntaire et Frs. 103,694 an foods de renon-vellement du matdriel, le oonseil propose de di8tribuer Frs. 6,25 par aotion privil4gi4e et Frs. 2,75 par action de dividende.
Les recettes de 1905 acoosent sur Texercioe pr4c4dent one augmentation de Frs. 219,571, tandis qne les d4penses ne se sont aoornes qne de Frs. 100,207.

Le rapport annonoe qne le conseil a 4t4 eaisi par un gronpe porteur d'environ 50,000 aotions d'nn projet d'unifioation des denx cat4-gories d'aotions, et qn'il 4tadie, d'apiks les statute, les moyens 14gaux qui permettraient d'arriver à la r4alisation de oe prrjet.

None prions in8tamment les pereonnes qui ne reipivent pas r4gnlikreiiient notre Circnlaire de none aviser sans retard afin qne nous puis-sions prendre des mesa res imm4 iates poor assurer la ponctualit4 da service d'exp4dition.

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
